reviewText: As any mother can attest - a little quite time is PRICELESS! I got the movie for one of my two nieces for her birthday. I thought it was a good value and was part of the prime shipping. Shortly after her birthday, I got a call from their mother thanking me for the "quiet time".  She said that she pops this baby in and the girls are transfixed for the duration of the movie. As she put it - just enough time for her to regain her sanity. Clearly an all around crowd pleaser!
summary: Great Value! Worth it for the quiet time!

reviewText: The Monster High videos are what well meaning if ultimately unhelpful activists in the bad old days of my youth used to call one hour commercials, that is animated children's TV shows based upon an existing line of toys.  (Frankly, I never understood the alleged vast moral difference between doing this as opposed to creating the TV show FIRST and only THEN merchandising the crap out of it with dolls, action figures, boardgames, Underoos, etc., but I digress.)  What matters most is the writing, and these videos are VERY well written!One of the things that makes the Monster High videos work so well is that the writers are gently making fun of the fashion doll mania that they are in fact trying to promote. Taking the universal American experience of High School and adding the twist of the entire student body being the children of famous monsters gives them endless possibilities for parody (and self parody, as the heroines are for the most part over the top, fashion crazed, popularity obsessed teenagers).  The animation and voice acting is no slouch, either!Chronologically the first movie is "Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love", which was the 3rd TV special, in fact the Valentine's Day Special.  Draculaura, Dracula's daughter, is turning Sweet 16, hundred that is, on February 14th, and the movie starts with what turns out to be Draculaura's idea for the perfect party,... to the horror of her ghoulfriends tasked with planning something that meets her insanely high expectations, though it turns out she comes by them honestly.  It seems that 400 years ago, her first boyfriend, a vampire named Valentine, created Valentine's Day just for her, but due to a "misunderstanding with the locals" (explained more fully in "Ghoul's Rule") she and her family had to flee the Old Country before the party so EVERY birthday/Valentine's Day party since gets measured in her mind against that first one she missed.Meanwhile, Monster High meany Toralei, miffed at not being invited to the party (because she's such a cruel jerk!), decides to get even by inviting Valentine (mimicking Draculaura's voice) to transfer to MH and renew their relationship.  Meanwhile, current Draculaura boyfriend, Clawd Wolf, facing similarly insanely high expectations, is walking the disaster strewn Path of "Practical Gifts".  After discovering that Draculaura is in real danger, and after C.A. Cupid misses the mark, quite literally, it is up to Draculaura's ghoulfriends to salvage a happy ending.  Gently Pushed Moral: Given the choice, dump the Fantasy in favor of the Real.Chronologically the second movie is "Friday Night Frights", which was the 5th TV special.  This is the story of how the MH version of Roller Derby (or is that Rollerball?) became coed after long tradition of male only teams, despite the fact that the first Skulltimate Roller Maze superstar a century ago was a girl, the mysteriously vanished Robecca Steam. Opening a year hence with the current coed team about to hit the floor, the movie flashes back a year to the Gravel City Gargoyles beating the MH team by cheating, which injured coach and best player Clawd Wolf (along with several other players) so badly that he's out for the season, effectively ending it for MH, until Frankie Stein gets another one of her crazy ideas: let ghouls play.  But this so goes against tradition that the remaining healthy male members quit the team in protest.  Now it is ALL up to our heroines to learn to play the game, to learn to WIN the game, to recruit the right ghouls, and to save their school (again, quite literally).  Gently Pushed Moral: Just because it's tradition doesn't mean it's good.Note: The earliest Monster High DVD was the 1st TV special "New Ghoul at School" but it was only made available in limited editions of the Dawn of the Dance series of dolls:Monster High Dawn Of The Dance Ghoulia Yelps Doll with exclusive DVD,Monster High Dawn Of The Dance Cleo De Nile Doll with exclusive DVD,Monster High Dawn Of The Dance Lagoona Blue Doll with exclusive DVD,Monster High Dawn Of The Dance Deuce Gorgon Doll with exclusive DVD, andMonster High Dawn Of The Dance 3 Pack: Clawdeen Wolf, Draculaura, and Frankie Stein Dolls with exclusive DVD,until recently when it was reissued as a retailer exclusive both separately and as part of a 2-pack with:the sixth Monster High DVD,Monster High: Clawesome Double Feature - Fright On! / Escape from Skull Shores, which contains the 2nd and 4th TV specials respectively.The second Monster High DVD wasMonster High: Ghouls Rule, which was the 6th TV special.The fourth Monster High DVD wasMonster High: 13 Wishes, which was the 9th TV special.The fifth Monster High DVD wasMonster High: Frights, Camera, Action!, which was the 10th TV special.
summary: Double the Commercials, Double the Fun
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?

reviewText: My wife and daughter have emmersed themselves in the Monster High concept and seem to be enjoying all the different facets of it. They look forward to more MH movies.As for the buying experience, the DVD arrived in a timely manner and in excellent condition.

reviewText: I will admit this is a very superficial show, but I love it. Theses ghouls are funny, cute, and trendy. It's not per say an educational show, but it's very entertaining. I find it cute and great for the girls or ghouls that just want to watch something fun. .
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?

reviewText: These were the first Monster High shows I ever watched.  I'm not basing this on the DVD release, but on the "movies" themselves.  Pretty much, the entire time, the girls in this movie are so extremely worried about their popularity, that it seldom moves beyond that point.  They're all worried about having the latest trends and all that BS.  It was so blatant, and in your face, it was difficult to find any more meaning to these movies than that.So, if you want your daughter(s) to grow up to be superficial, gold-diggers, these are the movies for you.  However, if you want your daughters to be productive members of society, with self-worth, look elsewhere.
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?

reviewText: We happened to rent a Monster High movies from a red box in the grocery store.  My 5-year old made the choice, not me.  We had never rented or watched anything Monster High in the past.  Within the 24 hours we were allowed to view the movie, we had to watch it about 6 times.  Then the next day (and the next day....and the next day...you get the drift) she kep asking for Monster High.  I opted to go see what Amazon had and found this double feature for $7.99 and bought it.Since we've received it we've watched it countless times.  I believe it has even pushed Frozen out of the "My Favorite" movie category in my daughter's list of all-time favorites.  Now that is major!  (She still loves the soundtrack to Frozen and HAS to listen to it in our van anywhere we go!)I give this double duo two big thumbs up!
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?

reviewText: Got this to watch with 9 year old.  We agreed it is really boring.  Very much focused on the cliches of high school conformism and stereotyping.  I wish monster really meant some engagement with difference and monstrosity, on a real level; this ain't it.

reviewText: My daughter LOVES Monster High toys, shows, books you name it. We've had these on the DVR forever and now she can watch them commercial free! If Monster High is your thing this is a great buy.
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?

reviewText: The Monster High Double features were both great short films the tween girls at our party loved. "Friday Night Frights". The girls compete against a team of gargoyles in a rolling skating derby. The ghouls learn the power of team playing and work together to bring home the gold for their school. I loved the message that it sent about girls being able to take on and defeat even the big guys.In "Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love". Draculara is celebrating her 1600th birthday and there are two boys who want a piece of her heart. She must choose between an old flame and the new man in her life. Along the way she learns to always trust her feelings and stay true to herself.
Title: Monster High Double Feature - Friday Night Frights / Why Do Ghouls Fall in Love?
